Furfuryl alcohol (FOL), as a cheap green biomass derivative, has high potential application value in the production of various biomass chemicals. In this work, a sulfonic acid functional porous organic polymer-coated carbon nanotubes catalyst (CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H) was successfully prepared. The structure of as-prepared catalysts was confirmed by TG/DTG, Raman spectra, TEM, FT-IR, N2 adsorption-desorption, and XPS measurements. The catalytic properties of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H were evaluated for the synthesis of n-butyl levulinate (BL) via the alcoholysis of FOL. It was found that the 99.1 % yield of BL was achieved under optimal conditions. The apparent activation energy of FOL to 2-bufurdoxy methyl-furan (BMF) and BMF to BL was 58.08 kJ/mol and 35.38 kJ/mol, respectively. This work provides a new avenue for the preparation of alkyl levulinates using FOL as raw material. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fuel bioadditive Catalysis Alcoholysis Furfuryl alcohol Alkyl levulinates Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The production of high-value, environmentally friendly chemicals using readily available and cost-effective biomass feedstocks has been a hot topic in the field of green chemistry [1–3]. Alkyl levulinates, a class of important platform compounds, can be used as green fuel additives, plasticizers, flavoring agents, and serve as precursors for the synthesis of high-value chemicals [4–11]. In particular, n-butyl levulinate (BL) exhibits substantial potential as an alternative diesel fuel, with the capability to significantly reduce carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon soot emissions [12]. Furfuryl alcohol (FOL) is a biomass-derived platform compound that can be further processed into valued-added products [13]. The alcoholysis of FOL is regarded as the most attractive and potential approach for the alkyl levulinates production [14]. In recent years, solid acid catalysts with the special morphologies, such as hollow structures, tube-like, and others, have been developed for this reaction. For examples, the silica-based material, dendritic fiber nanosilicon (DFNS) supported sulfonic acid group [15], can achieve high yield of alkyl levulinates, but the preparation method of catalyst is more complex. Moreover, heteropoly acid and ZrO2 dual-functional organosilicon nanotubes as well as ethane-bridged organosilica nanotubes functionalized with arene sulfonic acid and phenyl groups (ArSO3H-Si(Et)Si-Ph-NTs) were prepared by Song et al. [16,17], both of them can effectively convert levulinic acid or FOL into alkyl levulinates. It is worth noting that the carbon-based material due to low synthesis cost and abundant carbon sources make them more suitable heterogeneous catalytic systems than silica carriers [18,19]. Among the different types of carbon material, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) has recently attracted considerable interest in various fields ranging from electronics to hydrogen storage and high-strength composites due to their high specific surface area, adjustable electrical performance, extraordinary high specific strength and specific stiffness [20]. CNTs used as a support for solid acid catalyst has been further explored. Drelinkiewicz et al. found that CNTs supported polyaniline-sulfate could effectively catalyze transesterification of triacetin and castor oil with methanol [21]. Similarly, a series of polymer-carbon nanotube composites (CNT-P-SO3H) prepared by covalent grafting of CNTs with sulfonic acid-functionalized polymer exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the transesterification of triglycerides with methanol and the esterification reactions of oleic acid with methanol, respectively [22]. The above studies clearly demonstrated that CNTs used as excellent candidates could be rationally designed and modified by various directions, exhibiting great potentials for biomass conversion. In the present work, a sulfonic acid functional porous organic polymer-coated carbon nanotubes catalyst (CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H) was successfully prepared. The physical and chemistry properties of the catalysts were characterized by TG/DTG measurements, TEM, FT-IR, N2 adsorption-desorption and XPS. The factors affecting the catalytic efficiency of the catalyst were studied in the alcoholysis of FOL using the response surface method (RSM). The kinetics of alcoholysis of FOL and n-butanol were further analyzed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Chlorosulfonic acid (99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Xianding Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Levulinic acid (LA, 99 % purity) was purchased from Macklin. n-butyl levulinate (BL, 99 % purity) was purchased from Aladdin. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) was purchased Xianfeng Nanomaterials Technology Co., Ltd. Furfuryl alcohol, n-butanol (n-BuOH), ethanol, ammonia water (AR) and sodium hydroxide were procured from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of CNTs@PDVTA The purchased CNTs were initially subjected to nitric acid pretreatment, followed by thorough neutralization and drying for subsequent use [23]. Under a nitrogen-protected environment, 0.25 g of oxidized CNTs were combined with 6.25 g of diethylene benzene and 3 mL of polyethylene glycol in 300 mL of acetone for 1 h. 1.64 g of triacrylamine and 0.26 g of azodiisobutyronitrile (AIBN) was added to the mixture with stirring in 50 °C for 12 h. Then, the mixture was autoclaved at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained solid was washed three times with acetone and dried under vacuum to obtain fluffy gray-black solid powder (CNTs@PDVTA). The structure of PDVTA was shown in Scheme 1 . 2.2.2 Synthesis of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H A total of 1.7 g of CNTs@PDVTA was introduced into 200 mL of dichloromethane, along with 6 mL of chlorosulfonic acid. The mixture was agitated for a duration of 5 h within an ice water bath. The resulting solids were subsequently subjected to washing with ethanol and water until the filtrate reached a neutral state. The CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H product was then obtained after drying under vacuum conditions at 60 °C for a period of 3 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Thermo Nicdet infrared spectrophotometer using the KBr tablet technique. The morphologies of the samples were investigated by the transmission scanning microscopy (TEM) (JEOL 2100, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha. The sample was irradiated with a monochromatic Al K (1486.6 eV) radiation (12 kV; 6 mA). Binding energies were referenced to the C1s peak from the carbon surface deposit at 284.80 eV. The specific surface area and pore size of the material were determined by micromeritics ASAP 2460 nitrogen suction device. Thermal reanalysis was measured on NETZSCH-STA 409PC with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The Raman spectrum of the sample was determined using Thermo DXR, with focal length of 800 mm, 5 cm−1 of spectral resolution and 785 nm of excitation wavelength. 2.4 Determination of catalyst acidity The acid content of the prepared solid acid catalyst was determined by ion exchange method. A 50 mg sample of the catalyst was soaked in saturated salt water and subjected to ultrasonication for 30 min. Afterward, it was filtered and washed with deionized water. The obtained filtrate was titrated with a sodium hydroxide solution calibrated by potassium hydrogen phthalate. This entire procedure was repeated three times for accuracy. 2.5 Synthesis of n-butyl levulinate In a typical experiment, a combination of 1 mmol of FOL, 10 mL of n-butyl alcohol, 0.2 mmol of n-dodecane, and an appropriate quantity of catalyst were introduced into a round-bottom flask. The system was then heated and stirred utilizing an oil bath setup. After the reaction, the flask was quickly lifted to cool and the reaction liquid was analyzed by GC-2030 gas chromatograph and quantified by internal standard method. The chromatographic column was SH-RTX-1701 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and the reaction intermediates were determined by GC/MS-QP-2010. The alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol experiments were performed at least triplicate and all the furfuryl alcohol conversion and products selectivity data were presented as average values. FOL conversion ( % ) = ( initial moles of FOL − final moles of FOL ) / initial moles of FOL × 100 BL yield ( % ) = ( moles of BL / initial moles of FOL ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysis characterization Thermal gravimetric analysis, a crucial analytical technique, serves as a fundamental tool in the characterization of CNTs, enabling precise assessment and in-depth understanding of their thermal properties and behavior [24]. Fig. 1 illustrates a plot representing the percentage of mass with respect to temperature using a continuous solid line, alongside a dashed line that represents the first derivative of the weight with respect to temperature. Within the temperature range of 450–500 °C, there is an observable reduction in mass, which can be attributed to the structural deterioration of stereotypical carbon or single-wall CNTs, as supported by previous findings [25]. Furthermore, the distinct peak at 800 °C is associated with the decomposition of functional groups within the CNTs such as surface carboxylic anhydrides, lactones, phenols, carbonyl quinones and ether groups [26]. CNTs@PDVTA exhibits a distinct and well-defined weight loss peak at 454 °C, which aligns with the thermal decomposition temperatures of pure PDVTA material (442 °C) [27]. In addition, the temperature of weightlessness peak demonstrated an increase of approximately 10 °C, indicating that the incorporation of CNTs can indeed enhance the thermal stability of the PDVTA composite to some extent based on our previous work [28]. The CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H catalyst exhibits an initial weight loss, approximately 7 %, at approximately 100 °C, which corresponds to the desorption of surface-bound water, as indicated by the peak observed in the thermogravimetric analysis. The subsequent weight loss, accounting for approximately 60 % of the total, was observed at 470 °C. This can be attributed to the decomposition of various organic constituents within the CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H catalyst, including the CNTs@PDVTA framework and sulfonic groups. Thus, the CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H was thermodynamically stable at temperatures below 470 °C, which is much higher than the reported sulfonate polymer-carbon nanotube composite (branching multi-wall CNTs (227 °C), poly (4-vinyl-1-pyridyl chloride sulfonate)-branched multiwall CNTs (214 °C) and poly (4-styrene sulfonic acid)-branched multiwall CNTs (309 °C) [27,29]. Additionally, it is noteworthy that the used catalyst exhibited no substantial alterations, except for a subtle weight loss peak observed within the temperature range of 150–350 °C. This minor weight loss could potentially be attributed to structural alterations or damage within the catalyst [30]. Raman spectroscopy was employed to observe the impact of the polymerization and sulfonation processes on the properties of CNTs. As shown in Fig. 2 , the peak (D-band) near 1300 cm−1 was correlated with the vibration of the carbon atoms in the disordered graphite structure, corresponding to the tetrahedral carbon structure of sp3, the hybrid defective sp2 graphene edge structure, or other impurities. The peak near 1582 cm−1 (G band) related to the E2g vibration of sp2 hybrid carbon atoms in the grapheme structure. The G-peak was usually strongly influenced by defects, doping or stacking of graphene sheets [31]. In addition, the relative area ratio of D peak to G peak (ID/IG) was characterized the defects in the sp2 carbon material [32]. In this study, the oxidized CNTs modified by PDVTA, the value of ID/IG was increased from 0.93 to 0.97 (Table 1 ). This meaning that this process may be affect the structure of sp2-bonded carbon network and increases the disorder performance of the CNTs [33]. However, significant decreases happened to the CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H with the value of ID/IG was 0.56, which indicated that the CNTs@PDVTA was successfully functionalized with sulfonic acid groups. This result was consistent with the reported literature [22]. FT-IR spectra of catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The infrared absorption peak of the PDVTA-coated CNTs is somewhat different as compared to the pure PDVTA [27]. The peak at 1601 cm−1 represented the CC stretching vibration, and the peaks at 1485 cm−1 and 1444 cm−1 appear due to aromatic rings. The peak at 1361 cm−1 was ascribed to the stretching vibration of CN. The bond at 1340 cm−1 corresponded the infrared fingerprint of graphite nitrogen. After the sulfonation of the material, there were two new bands at 1170 cm−1 and 1036 cm−1, corresponding to the telescopic vibration of SO3 − and OSO, respectively, indicating that the sulfonic acid group was successfully grafted on the catalyst surface [28]. The broad peak centered at 3500 cm−1 assigned to the OH stretching mode which may be originated from OH, COOH or moisture containing in the sample. The CNTs@PDVTA and CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H were further characterized by TEM. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), (b), the outer surface of CNTs was rough, verifying the PDVTA are successfully grafted on the CNTs surface. In addition, it was clearly seen that the polymerization reaction in carbon nanotubes was limited to some extent [21,22,34]. For CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H, as shown in Fig. 4(c), (d), the integrity of the tube structure was not destroyed, indicating that the sulfation process does not destroy the tubular morphology of the catalyst. Moreover, the outer diameter and the inner diameter was 70–160 nm and 10–40 nm, respectively, while the ratio of the outer diameter to the inner diameter was in the range of 4–7 nm. There is no significant change in the inner diameter, indicating that the sulfonation process will not block the pipe structure. The XPS is one of the most widely used techniques for characterizing the functionalized CNTs [35–37]. The XPS plots of the sulfonated samples are showed in Fig. 5 (a), and then Fig. 5(b) shows the carbon profile of CNTs@PDVTA before and after sulfonation. The dominant peak at 284.5 eV was assigned to the presence of CC and CC bonds [38], and the peak at 291.1 eV was corresponding to the satellite peak π-π* in nitrogen-doped graphene [39]. In addition, the intensity of graphite carbon peak located at 285.5 eV was decreased after the sulfation treatment, which could be attributed to the CS bond in the sulfation material [40,41]. In Fig. 5(c), the binding energy of N located at 399.58 eV was consistent with the peak position of pyrrole nitrogen, whose center appeared in the pentagon ring of sp2 hybrids [42]. After the grafted sulfonic acid functional group, a new peak at 402.08 eV corresponded to the graphite-nitrogen structure was observed. It is worth mentioning that graphite nitrogen structure maintains the symmetry and electron conjugation of the graphene lattice, so that the charge transfer of each N atom is much larger than in the case of pyrrole N [43]. The peak of the oxygen elements located at 532.95 eV, including the CO bond as well as the chemisorbed oxygen [36]. The peak at 532.18 eV was assigned to OS bond [40]. More peaks at 533.78 eV can be attributed to the sulfonic acid group and the binding energy of water [36,40]. The high-resolution sulfur spectra (Fig. 5(e)) shows that S 2p presented two peaks with binding energies of 168.48 eV and 169.58 eV, which can be assigned to the sulfur oxide [44]. The above results demonstrate that the sulfation process effectively changes the chemical environment of the nitrogen elements in PDVTA [45], suggesting that the sulfonic acid group was successfully grafted on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 6 , the surface area of the oxidized CNTs was increased when compared to the original CNTs because the oxidation of concentrated nitric acid reduces the CNTs impurities, increasing the number of ports and micropores [46]. Hence, the introduction of the sulfonic acid group does not block the pore of CNTs. The final material (CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H) has a specific surface area of 533 m2 g−1 and a pore capacity of 0.38 cm3 g−1 (Table 2 ), which far more than the data reported by other organic polymer sulfated modified CNTs [22]. This material has a class IV isotherm with a hysteresis loops, corresponding to the system of porous catalyst. Both the raw carbon and oxidized CNTs have H4 hysteresis loops, and after PDVTA coating, the hysteresis loop of the material turns to H3, indicating that the polymer coating alters the CNTs, shifting them from a combination of microholes and medium-sized holes to a material characterized by slit, crack, and wedge structures. A moderate increase of chlorosulfonic acid can increase the acid density of the catalyst. When the ratio of chlorosulfonic acid to CNTs@PDVTA is 3 mL/g, the amount acid of as-prepared catalyst is up to 1.73 mmol/g. However, a further increase in the quantity of chlorosulfonic acid results in a notable reduction in the catalyst's acidity, implying that an excessively high acid concentration might induce structural damage to the catalyst [47]. 3.2 Catalysts performance evaluation 3.2.1 Effects of reaction time To methodically explore the impact of experimental variables on the catalytic reaction, we conducted investigations into the effects of reaction time, temperature, catalyst dosage, and FOL concentration. Initially, we conducted an examination of the influence of reaction time on the catalytic reaction. As can be seen in Fig. 7 , FOL can be completely transformed within 10 min, but the selectivity of the target product BL was slowly increased. Meanwhile, the intermediate 2-butoxy methyl furan (BMF) as an important product was detected in the early stage of this reaction [48,49], indicating that the conversion of the intermediate to BL is a critical step during the reaction process. Then extended the reaction time, BL selectivity slowly increased to 99.0 % after 12 h. These results show that it takes a longer time to reach the reaction equilibrium. 3.2.2 Effects of temperature The influence of reaction temperature on the alcoholysis of FOL was explored and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . Obviously, elevated temperatures are more favorable for the conversion of intermediates into the desired end product. At 120 °C, BL selectivity was up to 100 %. It's important to note that, under atmospheric pressure, the catalyst system can only reach the solvent's boiling point temperature. Hence, this work did not further increase the reaction temperature further for investigation. 3.2.3 Effects of catalyst dosage The effect of catalyst dosage on the alcoholysis reaction was examined, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . When gradually increasing the catalyst dosage to 0.06 g, the selectivity of BL was gradually increased to 92 %. Continuing to increase the catalyst dosage, the selectivity of BL is less significant. When the amount of the catalyst reached 0.15 g, the BL had the highest selectivity of 98.7 %. Subsequently, the selectivity of BL decreased with the further increase of catalyst dosage, which maybe this process experience significant the mass transfer limitations owing to the excessive catalyst [50]. 3.2.4 Effects of different alcohols To further illustrate the substrate universality of the catalyst, a variety of alkyl alcohols were selected and investigated at the corresponding reflux temperature. As can be seen from the Table 3 , the selectivity of methyl levulinate (ML) and EL was 22.8 % and 54.5 %, respectively. This may be due to the relatively low temperature of the catalytic system. It should be noted that the boiling point of isopropyl alcohol is close to that of ethanol, but the reaction effect of isopropyl alcohol as substrate was obviously better than that of ethanol, which may be due to the exists of 2-isopropyloxymethofuran as the intermediate product is more likely to remove alkyl alcohol, thus promoting the positive progress of the reaction [51]. n-Propanol has a relatively high boiling point, and the selectivity of target product remained at about 86.6 %. 3.3 Response surface analysis To optimize the reaction process, the optimal response conditions were further explored by the response surface method [52]. In this study, three parameters such as reaction temperature, catalyst dosage, molar ratio of FOL to n-butanol were selected as variables. 17 sets of experiments were designed by Box–Behnken experiment with the yield of BL as the response value at 3 h, and the designed variable level and experimental results are shown in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively. The results of the analysis of variance (ANOVA) of the experimental data are listed in Table 6 . It can be seen that the p-value of the fitted model was less than 0.0001, and the p-value of “Lack of Fit” is 0.0806, indicating that the fitting degree of between the predicted values and the test values is good using this model. Response variables can be represented by the following equation. Y ( BL yield ) = 83.88 − 0.17 A + 21.43 B + 8.75 C + 1.90 AB + 8.30 AC − 6.35 BC − 4.77 A 2 − 18.67 B 2 + 4.18 C 2 All three parameters, molar ratio of FOL to n-butanol (A), catalyst dosage (B) and temperature (C), show a primary effect on BL yield. Among them, the catalyst dosage is the most significant factor for BL production. Furthermore, the order of the interaction between the different factors was BC > AB > AC, indicating that the BL yield was significantly affected by the interaction between catalyst dosage and temperature. As can be seen from Fig. 10 (a), the yield of BL was greatly affected by the catalyst dosage, but was less affected by the mole ratio of FOL/n-butanol. Fig. 10(b) shows the response surface for the interaction of between temperature and FOL concentration. When the mole ratio of FOL to n-butanol was low, the effect of temperature dominates the yield of BL. Fig. 10(c) shows the effect of the catalyst dosage and temperature on the yield of BL. It can be clearly seen that, the interaction between catalyst dosage and temperature was so remarkable when the catalyst dosage was lower than 0.06 g. Based on the above analysis results, the optimal conditions for the model were temperature of 120 °C, catalyst load of 68 wt.% and the molar ratio of FOL to n-butanol of 0.07. Under the experimental conditions, FOL conversion and BL yield reached to 100 % and 99.1 %, respectively. In addition, in order to test the recyclability of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H, the consecutive runs was carried out under the optimum conditions. The activity loss of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H was neglectable after three cycles, and a yield of the desired product BL was still kept at 95.3 %. The TGA curve (Fig. 1) and infrared spectra (Fig. 3) of the used catalyst did not change significantly compared with the fresh catalyst, which indicates that the catalyst structure is stable. 3.4 Reaction mechanism and kinetic study The reaction mechanism of alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol to n-butyl levulinate in the presence of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H catalyst was proposed and shown in Scheme 2 . The furfuryl alcohol molecules are first activated and protonated by the SO3H sites of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H catalyst. Then, the intermediate product, BMF, was formed via the n-butanol molecule attacking the protonated furfuryl alcohol. After being added and withdrawn of n-butanol in the presence of strong SO3H groups, respectively, the intermediate I is formed. Subsequently, the intermediate I undergoes protonation to give cyclic oxonium (intermediate II). The intermediate II further undergoes the ring-open reaction in the presence of H2O and Brønsted acid sites, giving the another intermediate III. At last, the BL is formed via the isomerization [48,53]. The apparent activation energies for forming BL from FOL using CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H as catalyst was further evaluated at different temperatures (50, 70, 90, 100 °C), while other factors were kept fixed. The reaction steps for the alcoholysis of FOL can be simplified as the following [48]: It can be further abbreviated as: where A, B, and C represent FOL, BMF and BL, respectively. Supposing that the molar concentration of furfuryl alcohol, B and C at the beginning of the reaction was a, 0 and 0, respectively. At t time, the concentration of A, B and C can be written as x, y and z, respectively. The net rate of generating B is equal to its generating rate minus the consumption rate, which can be simplified as Eqs. (1)–(3): (1) − d x d t = k 1 x (2) d y d t = k 1 x − k 2 y (3) d z d t = k 2 y The equations can be further expressed as following: (4)–(7), (4) l n a x = k 1 t (5) d y d t = k 1 a e − k 1 t − k 2 y (6) y = k 1 a k 2 − k 1 ( e − k 1 t − e − k 2 t ) (7) z = a ( 1 − k 2 k 2 − k 1 e − k 1 t + k 1 k 2 − k 1 e − k 2 t ) As shown in Fig. 11 , the concentration of FOL was decreased significantly with increasing temperature, while BMF increased first and then decreased with the reaction time. According to the experimental results and the kinetic equations, the kinetic data obtained are listed in Table 7 . The reaction rates of the two steps increase with increasing temperature, which proves that the two steps are endothermic reactions [54]. As seen from Fig. 12 , the linear kinetic relationship between lnk and reaction time is highly consistent with the pseudo-level hypothesis established by the model ( R 1 2 , R 2 2 > 0.95 ), indicating the reliability of the model. The apparent activation energies required for the FOL to BMF and the intermediate BMF to BL were found to 58.08 kJ/mol and 35.38 kJ/mol, respectively. The estimated activation energy is lower than the activation energy of direct conversion FOL to BL [51]. The kinetic results indicated CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H was efficient catalyst for the conversion of FOL to BL. 4 Conclusions In this work, a novel heterogeneous catalyst CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H with a high-density acid sites and abundant pore structure was prepared and showed good catalytic performance in the alcoholysis of FOL to produce BL. The interplay of various reaction parameters on the alcoholysis of FOL was investigated, and a reliable reaction model was established to predict experimental outcomes accurately. A remarkable BL yield of 99.1 % was attained under the reaction conditions of 120 °C and a reaction time of 3 h. The apparent activation energies required for the FOL to the intermediate BMF and BMF to BL were 58.08 kJ/mol and 35.38 kJ/mol, respectively, demonstrating that CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H significantly reduced the activation energy in the step of intermediate BMF to BL. The CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H catalyst offers a novel technical approach for synthesizing various alkyl levulinates from biomass-derived FOL. coredata.dc:description: Furfuryl alcohol (FOL), as a cheap green biomass derivative, has high potential application value in the production of various biomass chemicals. In this work, a sulfonic acid functional porous organic polymer-coated carbon nanotubes catalyst (CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H) was successfully prepared. The structure of as-prepared catalysts was confirmed by TG/DTG, Raman spectra, TEM, FT-IR, N2 adsorption-desorption, and XPS measurements. The catalytic properties of CNTs@PDVTA-SO3H were evaluated for the synthesis of n-butyl levulinate (BL) via the alcoholysis of FOL. It was found that the 99.1 % yield of BL was achieved under optimal conditions. The apparent activation energy of FOL to 2-bufurdoxy methyl-furan (BMF) and BMF to BL was 58.08 kJ/mol and 35.38 kJ/mol, respectively. This work provides a new avenue for the preparation of alkyl levulinates using FOL as raw material.
coredata.dc:title: A novel sulfonated solid acid catalyst for efficient conversion of furfuryl alcohol to n-butyl levulinate fuel bioadditive
